ab initio.usage: Used to indicate that something is void from its inception, as if it never existed.
ab initio.example: The contract was declared void ab initio.

actus reus.usage: The physical element of a crime - the wrongful deed itself.
actus reus.example: To establish a crime, both actus reus and mens rea must be proven.

audi alteram partem.usage: Principle of natural justice - no one should be condemned unheard.
audi alteram partem.example: The order was quashed for violation of audi alteram partem.

bona fide.example: The purchaser was a bona fide buyer for value.

caveat emptor.usage: Buyer takes risk of quality of goods purchased.
caveat emptor.example: Under caveat emptor, it was the buyer's duty to inspect the goods.

de facto.usage: Existing in reality, though not officially recognized.
de facto.example: He was the de facto head of the organization.

de jure.example: The de jure owner retained legal title to the property.

ex parte.usage: Proceedings where only one party is present.
ex parte.example: An ex parte order was passed in the petitioner's absence.

habeas corpus.usage: Writ to produce detained person before court.
habeas corpus.example: A habeas corpus petition was filed challenging the detention.

in personam.usage: Rights or actions enforceable against a specific person.
in personam.example: The decree is in personam, binding only on the defendant.

in rem.usage: Rights enforceable against the world at large.
in rem.example: Property rights are rights in rem.

inter alia.usage: Used when listing items that are part of a larger set.
inter alia.example: The petition challenged, inter alia, the constitutional validity.

ipso facto.usage: As an inevitable result of the action.
ipso facto.example: Death of the partner ipso facto dissolves the partnership.

locus standi.usage: Right to bring an action or be heard in court.
locus standi.example: The petitioner lacks locus standi to challenge the Act.

mens rea.usage: The mental element of a crime - criminal intent.
mens rea.example: Mens rea is an essential ingredient of most criminal offenses.

modus operandi.example: The accused followed the same modus operandi in all cases.

mutatis mutandis.usage: Applying same principle with appropriate modifications.
mutatis mutandis.example: The same ratio applies mutatis mutandis to the present case.

nemo judex in causa sua.meaning: No one should be judge in their own cause
nemo judex in causa sua.usage: Principle against bias - judges must be impartial.
nemo judex in causa sua.example: The order violated nemo judex in causa sua principle.

obiter dictum.usage: Incidental remarks by judge, not binding precedent.
obiter dictum.example: The observation was merely obiter dictum.

pari passu.example: The creditors shall be paid pari passu.

per curiam.usage: Decision by the whole court rather than single judge.
per curiam.example: The judgment was delivered per curiam.

prima facie.meaning: At first appearance / On the face of it
prima facie.usage: Evidence sufficient to establish fact unless rebutted.
prima facie.example: A prima facie case of negligence has been made out.

pro bono.usage: Legal services provided free of charge.
pro bono.example: The advocate appeared pro bono for the indigent accused.

quid pro quo.usage: Exchange of value, consideration in contracts.
quid pro quo.example: Every valid contract requires quid pro quo.

ratio decidendi.usage: The legal principle on which a decision is based.
ratio decidendi.example: The ratio decidendi of the judgment is binding precedent.

res judicata.usage: Doctrine preventing relitigation of decided issues.
res judicata.example: The suit is barred by res judicata.

sine qua non.example: Negligence is the sine qua non of the tort.

stare decisis.example: The court is bound by stare decisis to follow the ruling.

status quo.example: Status quo shall be maintained during pendency of the suit.

suo motu.usage: Court acting on its own without petition.
suo motu.example: The court took suo motu cognizance of the matter.

ultra vires.example: The order was ultra vires the statute.

vis major.example: The flood was vis major, excusing performance.
